Award.AwardTitle: IGERT: Graduate Program in Computational Transportation Science

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration: This Integrative Graduate Education and Research Traineeship (IGERT) award establishes a graduate training program in the Information Technology aspects of Transportation Science. Computational transportation scientists will develop the next generation of intelligent transportation systems, aimed at addressing inefficiencies that cause excessive environmental pollution, fuel consumption, risk to public safety, and congestion. IGERT trainees will investigate technologies in which sensors, traveler-devices such as PDAs, in-vehicle computers, and computers in the static infrastructure are integrated into a collaborative environment. Trainees will also investigate both how these technologies are adopted and their impacts. The envisioned transportation environment will incorporate the technologies, enabling solutions to problems such as dynamic ride-sharing, real-time routing, and navigation. Basic research in information management, communications, software architectures, modeling tools, human factors, traffic prediction, and transportation planning will be utilized to found a new discipline that will integrate millions of highly mobile computers and sensors into a collaborative system. IGERT trainees will use a prototype test-bed application that will integrate the results of their research. This prototype is a software system that runs on hand-held computers, and plans optimal trajectories for a traveler using multiple modes of transportation (e.g., bus and then train). The education of trainees will be facilitated by student-faculty co-teaching, student shared workspace, student collaboration, and the requirement for an internship. The broader impacts of this grant include transportation planning professionals who can save the country the costs of excessive petroleum products consumption, environmental pollution, congestion, and traffic fatalities. IGERT is an NSF-wide program intended to meet the challenges of educating U.S. Ph.D. scientists and engineers with the interdisciplinary background, deep knowledge in a chosen discipline, and the technical, professional, and personal skills needed for the career demands of the future. The program is intended to catalyze a cultural change in graduate education by establishing innovative new models for graduate education and training in a fertile environment for collaborative research that transcends traditional disciplinary boundaries.

POR.DRECONTENT:
From self-driving cars, to Uber ride-sharing/taxi-hailing, to Google navigation based on real-time traffic, changes in transportation fundamentals are profound, and they promise to revolutionize mobility. The CTS-IGERT (Integrative Graduate Education and Research Traineeship in Computational Transportation Science) program was designed to effectively develop, research, and teach Intelligent Transportation skills to graduate students in a multidisciplinary environment. Specifically, the research in CTS was focused on the transportation aspects of information technology. To build intelligent transportation systems, the CTS research aimed to promote transportation safety, increase mobility, and reduce pollution, fuel consumption, and congestion. Various types of technologies were investigated, such as sensors, smartphones, and in-vehicle computers. The problem of how to integrate them into a collaborative environment was also investigated and solutions were proposed. A prototype of the Intelligent Traveler Assistant (ITA) was developed. Components of the ITA include traffic information provision, parking detection and navigation, real-time transit navigation, driver emergency warnings, dynamic ridesharing. CTS research developed tools in information management, communications, software architectures, modeling, human factors, traffic prediction, and transportation planning. As a result, CTS was established as a new discipline that integrates these aspects.

The IGERT program brought together graduate students from multidisciplinary backgrounds. It deepened their knowledge in their chosen discipline, and prepared their technical, professional, and personal skills for future careers in Computational Transportation. The trainees of this program benefited from co-teaching classes with faculty members, conducting research in a multidisciplinary environment, collaborating with other students and faculty members, and conducting internships outside the campus. An interdisciplinary CTS colloquium was held weekly. Faculty members from various departments were involved, including Computer Science, Civil and Materials Engineering, Urban Planning and Policy, Mechanical and Industrial Engineering, and Mathematics and Statistics. As a result, an environment of collaborative research that transcends traditional disciplinary boundaries was created. Multidisciplinary co-teaching and co-advising was practiced.

The program generated over 350 peer-reviewed publications and three awarded patents, with 16 pending. Technologies were put in the public domain.

Graduates went on to careers in industrial labs such as Motorola Mobility, Nokia, Amazon, and academia.
